content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="M g, solid, plus 2 H C l, aqueous, react to produce M g C l 2, aqueous, plus H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>2</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>MgCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> In an experiment, a student places a small piece of pure <math alttext="M g, solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> into a beaker containing <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="6.44 molar H C l, aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.44</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. A reaction occurs, as represented by the equation above. (a) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction between <math alttext="M g, solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>HCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> </semantics> </math>.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="M g, solid, plus 2 H C l, aqueous, react to produce M g C l 2, aqueous, plus H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>2</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>MgCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> In an experiment, a student places a small piece of pure <math alttext="M g, solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> into a beaker containing <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="6.44 molar H C l, aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.44</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. A reaction occurs, as represented by the equation above. (a) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction between <math alttext="M g, solid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>HCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> </semantics> </math>.

(b) The student collects the <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by the reaction and measures its volume over water at <math alttext="298 Kelvin"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>298 K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> after carefully equalizing the water levels inside and outside the gas-collection tube, as shown in the diagram below. The volume is measured to be <math alttext="45.6 milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45.6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The atmospheric pressure in the lab is measured as <math alttext="765 torr"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>765 torr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the equilibrium vapor pressure of water at <math alttext="298 Kelvin"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>298 K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="24 torr"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24 torr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the following. (i) The pressure inside the tube due to the <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

(ii) The number of moles of <math alttext="H 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> produced in the reaction

(c) In a different experiment, a student places a piece of pure <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>Ba</mtext> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> </semantics> </math> in a beaker containing <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="6.44 molar H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.44</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and observes that the rate of appearance of <math alttext="H 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> bubbles when <math alttext="B a, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added is much faster than the rate of appearance of bubbles when the <math alttext="M g, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>g</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added. The student claims that the greater reactivity is due to the difference in ionization energy between <math alttext="M g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain the difference in ionization energy between <math alttext="M g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of atomic structure.

<math alttext="H C l"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be produced by the exothermic reaction <math alttext="H 2 gas, plus 2 I C l gas, react to produce 2 H C l gas, plus I 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>ICl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. A proposed mechanism for the reaction has two elementary steps as shown below. Step 1: <math alttext="H 2 gas, plus I C l gas, react to produce H l gas, plus H C l gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>ICl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mtext>HI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> (slow) Step 2: <math alttext="H I gas, plus I C l gas, react to produce H C l gas, plus I 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>ICl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> (fast) (d) Write a rate law for the overall reaction that is consistent with the proposed mechanism.

(e) On the incomplete reaction energy diagram below, draw a curve that shows the following two details. The relative activation energies of the two elementary steps The enthalpy change of the overall reaction

skill.text: 3.B: Represent chemical substances or phenomena with appropriate diagrams or models (e.g., electron configuration).
